War in Ukraine: Peace talks hit a wall of Russian intransigence
byline: By Claire Gatinois, Marie Jégo and Philippe Ricard
subhed: Despite 'significant progress' cited by European officials, negotiations appear to be going in circles. The close relationship between US negotiators and the Kremlin has fueled distrust among Kyiv's allies, who are meeting Thursday in Brussels to decide the fate of frozen Russian assets.

title: Louvre president and her predecessor trade blame in French Sénat hearings
French court jails doctor for life for poisoning 30 patients, killing 12
Farmers block roads in Brussels to protest South American free-trade deal
subhed: European farmers fear the deal will undercut their livelihoods, as it would progressively remove duties on almost all goods traded between the two blocs over the next 15 years.

title: How UN agencies maintain operations despite massive layoffs
subhed: The US's decision to freeze a significant portion of its funding for the United Nations has accelerated the overhaul of the UN system, which is now grappling with a major operational crisis.

title: Russia bets on sports to regain international standing
byline: By Nicolas Lepeltier and Benjamin Quénelle
subhed: Moscow has scored back-to-back victories. Its judokas can now compete worldwide with flag and anthem, and its skiers are eligible for the Olympics. To bring its athletes back, Moscow has focused on legal battles and 'sharp power,' a variant of soft power.

title: Bovine skin disease: Massive vaccination campaign pits some farmers against veterinarians
subhed: The French government has launched a large-scale effort to vaccinate 750,000 cattle in southwestern France as quickly as possible to protect them against the outbreak of Lumpy skin disease. However, farmers' mistrust of veterinarians complicates the immense logistical challenge.

byline: By Martin Untersinger, Arthur Carpentier, Damien Leloup and Florian Reynaud

title: 'It is easier to flatter the people than to serve. Therein lies the last obstacle to an RN victory in 2027'
subhed: Populism has never been stronger in France, but there is a crucial difference between flattering the people and serving them, and the Rassemblement National is currently stumbling on that divide, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: A French farmer's distress: 'I found the first dead cow when I went to the pasture'
subhed: Near Benque, a village an hour from Toulouse, farmer Christian Lasserre discovered three carcasses on Saturday. He fears a new outbreak of lumpy skin disease and the culling of the entire herd.

title: In Paris, the number of homeless living in outdoor camps continues to rise
subhed: Outreach teams counted 663 tents in the main encampment areas of the French capital at the end of November, representing between 985 and 1,723 people. The rise is driven by a reduction in available shelter spaces and tighter restrictions on residency permits.
